Award.AwardTitle: International Conference on Harmonic Analysis and Its Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "International Conference on Harmonic Analysis and Its Applications" that will be held June 1-5, 2015, at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.

This conference brings together specialists from different parts of harmonic analysis and its applications, among them experts in classical harmonic analysis, in frame analysis, and in the study of large data sets. Some of the specific topics that will be discussed at the event are the following: analysis and geometry of high-dimensional data sets; compressive sensing; diffusion geometry; frame and wavelet theory; homogeneous spaces; interpolation spaces; phase retrieval; Radon transforms; sampling theory; sigma-delta quantization; signal and image processing; symmetric spaces and Paley-Wiener spaces; time-frequency analysis; visualization and learning theory. The list of featured speakers includes Peter Casazza, Ronald Coifman, Palle Jorgensen, Adam Koranyi, Michael Lacey, Mauro Maggioni, and Elias Stein. The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"International Conference in Harmonic Analysis and Applications"

NSF Award # 1501066

This is the report on the NSF grant funding for the conference, entitled "International Conference in Harmonic Analysis and Applications" that took place at the City University of New York Graduate Center on June 1- June 5, 2015. The following mathematicians delivered excellent, well-attended lectures at the conference:  

Farras Abdelnour, Weill Cornell Medical College, Predicting brain's functional network from structure's Laplacian

Akram Aldroubi, Vanderbilt university, Dynamical Sampling, cyclical sets, cyclical frames sets and the spectral theory 

John J. Benedetto, Norbert Wiener Center, University of Maryland, College Park,  Frames from signal processing and back again a sampling

 Radu Balan, Norbert Wiener Center, University of Maryland, College Park, Phase Retrieval using Lipschitz Continuous Maps 

Peter G. Casazza, University of Missouri, Phase Retrieval

Jens Christensen, Colgate University, New Atomic Decompositions of Bergman Spaces

Bradley Currey, St. Louis University,  Detecting admissible dilation groups

Jacqueline Davis, Arizona State University, Fast Imaging Techniques using Fourier Frames 

Matt Dawson, CIMAT,  Commuting Toeplitz Operators and Holomorphic Discrete Series Representation 

 Laura De Carli, Florida international university,  From Exponential Bases to the Discrete Hilbert Transform 

C. Sinan Gunturk, Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU , Beta duals of frames and near-optimal quantization

Sigurdur Helgason, MIT,  Spherical Functions and Radon Transforms

Eugenio Hernandez, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, Frame sequences and operator valued bracket maps

Adam Koranyi, Lehman College, and the Graduate Center, CUNY, Holomorphically induced representations of SU(2,1)

Richard Lynch, University of Missouri, Weaving Frames

Mauro Maggioni, Duke University, Multiscale Geometric Methods for Statistical Learning and Data in High-Dimensions

Thao Nguyen, City College, CUNY, Finite-power sequences: misconceptions, facts, and their role in the spectral analysis of sigma-delta quantization

Shahaf Nitzan, Kent State University, Exponential Frames on Unbounded Sets

Judith A. Packer, University of Colorado at Boulder, Wavelets associated to representations of graph $C^*$ -algebras

Eyvindur A. Palsson, Williams College, Finite point configurations

 Isaac Pesenson, Temple University, Parseval Localized Frames for Subelliptic Function Spaces on Compact Manifolds

Jill Pipher, Brown University and ICERM, Carleson measures and elliptic and parabolic boundary value problems

 Alex Powell, Vanderbilt University, Consistent reconstruction and randomized recovery algorithms

 Scott Spencer, Georgia Institute of Technology, Entropy Bumps for Calderon-Zygmund Operators

 Elias Stein, Princeton University, The Cauchy-Szego projection in several complex variables

Diana T. Stoeva, Acoustics Research Institute, Austrian Academy of Sciences, The duality principle in Gabor analysis and in general Hilbert spaces

Ignacio Uriarte-tuero, Michigan State University, Two weight norm inequalities for singular and fractional integral operators in Rn : T1 theorems


Six of these speakers are women or disadvantaged minorities. The conference was attended by a large number of the following graduate students who attended the lectures and successfully interacted with senior mathematicians.

  11. Joey Iverson, University of Oregon
  12. Halyun Jeong, Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU
  13. Michael Kumaresan, the Graduate Center, CUNY
  14. Ishwari Kunwar, Georgia Institute of Technology
  15.  Kil H. Kwon, KAIST
  16. William Leeb, Yale University
  17.  Wenjing Liao, Duke University
  18. Ian Long, University of Colorado at Boulder
  19.  Richard Lynch, University of Missouri
  20. John Marinelli, College of Staten Island, CUNY
  21. Anirudha Poria, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati
  22. Bob Putz, CUNY
  23. Robert Rahm, Georgia Tech
  24. Mads Sielemann Jakobsen, Technical University of Denmark
  25. Timothy Scott Spencer, Georgia Tech
  26. Felix Voigtlaender, RWTH Aachen, Germany
  27. Jieren Xu, Duke University
  28. Max Yarmolinsky, the Graduate Center, CUNY
  29.  Lei Yin, New York University

One of the most important and successful features of this conference was the presence of mathematicians from several different areas of mathematics. The wavelet folks interacted very productively with the number theorists. Professor John Benedetto played a particularly constructive role in this regard by engaging all the lecturers in detailed discussions with emphasis on connections between different techniques and ideas.

 

The success of this conference shows that the underlying paradigm is very solid and bodes well for the future conferences at the same location. We hope to repeat the conference in a similar format in June 2017
